caseTitle: Aurangzaib v. M/s Medipak (Pvt.) Ltd. and others
tagline: Two things need be shown by a person who seeks to bring his claim under the Payment of Wages Act, 1936 (“1936 Act”): firstly, that he was a "person employed", and secondly, that he was employed in either a "factory" or an "industrial establishment" or a "commercial establishment". The Labour Laws (Amendment) Ordinance, 2001 (“2001 Ordinance”) has expanded the scope of the 1936 Act manifold. There never was, and certainly after the 2001 Ordinance no longer is, any requirement that the claimant establish himself to be a "workman".
